title: NICER
name: NICER
alttext: NICER mounted on the International Space Station
descript: The Neutron star Interior Composition ExploreR (NICER) is an NASA experiment placed on the International Space Station (ISS). NICER observed the sky in the X-ray band (0.2–12 keV) with large collective area and fine time resolution. It was launched on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket on June 3, 2017, and commenced operations on June 14. The mission was approved for 18 months of operations that was extended in March 2019. The mission is currently suspended since 17 Jun 2025 when a hardware anomaly in the pointing system made it impossible to track sources.
features: Concentrator optics with high temporal and moderate spectral resolution

instruments.descript: XTI consists of aligned collection of 56 X-ray “concentrator” optics (XRC) and silicon drift detector (SDD) pairs. Each XRC collects X-rays over a large geometric area from a roughly 30 arcmin<sup>2</sup> region of the sky and focuses them onto a small SDD. The SDD detects individual photons, recording their energies with good (few percent) spectral resolution and their detection times to an unprecedented 100 nanoseconds RMS relative to Universal Time. Together, this assemblage provides a high signal-to-noise-ratio photon-counting capability within the 0.2–12 keV X-ray band, perfectly matched to the typical spectra of neutron stars as well as a broad collection of other astrophysical sources.

highlights: Demonstration of Station Explorer for X-ray Timing and Navigation Technology (SEXTANT) using pulsar timing to provide navigation
Investigate extreme gravity, density and magnetic fields found in neutron stars
Measure neutron stars radius and mass with increased accuracy
